newsitem.title: UK: Nervous Bradys stick to U.S. Treasury path.
newsitem.headline: Nervous Bradys stick to U.S. Treasury path.

text.p: Emerging market debt nervously swayed with U.S. Treasuries on Tuesday and traders said the market will remain jittery.
"Until we see a floor in Treasuries, you won't see anything in Bradys," one European bank trader said.
"There's almost no liquidity. People must be desperate to trade at the moment," he added.
Most of the market is waiting for New York to open and to see what happens on Wall Street.
Even after that there is the long wait for Friday's non-farm payroll data to give another clue on the direction of U.S. interest rates.
East European debt was softer, following on from Monday's drop in New York with Wall Street's falling fortunes.
Russian Vneshekonombank dollar debt RUVNUSLNS=RR is now at its recent lows of around 77 cents in the dollar, down from a record high earlier in the year of 87 cents.
"Russia can't buck the trend. It's going to be a nervous, spooky market this week," another trader said.
MinFin bonds, which had been hit in the past two trading days, were about unchanged by late morning after choppy trading.
The impact of weak U.S. Treasuries has been compounded by concerns over delays in closing Russia's agreement with commercial banks on old Soviet debt.
Elsewhere, news that Bulgaria had finally closed one of its troubled banks had little effect, traders said.
A Bulgarian court on Monday declared state-owned Mineralbank insolvent.
It is the first state-owned bank to go after the programme to deal with the banking sector was introduced almost a year ago.
"Hopefully with this government in place, there will be more (closures)," Merrill Lynch analyst Andrew Kenningham said.
